transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: Hello, thank you for participating in this interview. I'm going to ask you some questions about your health and experiences. Let's begin.

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text: Hello, thank you for having me. I'm glad to participate in this interview. Please go ahead with the questions.

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: Can you tell me a bit about yourself and your current life situation?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text: Sure! As I mentioned, my name is Olivia, and I'm 41 years old. I live in suburban Seattle and work as a high school teacher. I have a master's degree, which I earned a few years ago. I’m divorced and have two children from my previous marriage. They’re both in their teens now, so life can be a bit hectic with their activities and school. I’m moderately health-conscious; I try to exercise when I can, but it can be challenging with my busy schedule. I have hypertension, which I manage with medication. I also have chronic sinusitis, which can be bothersome at times. Overall, I feel fortunate to have good healthcare access through Medicare. How about you? What would you like to know next?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: Can you tell me about your pregnancy or pregnancies? When did you first learn you were pregnant?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text: I first learned I was pregnant when I was in my late twenties. I remember being both excited and a bit overwhelmed at the news. I had my first child shortly after, and then I had my second child a couple of years later. Those pregnancies were quite different from each other, but I was fortunate to have relatively healthy pregnancies overall. I did experience a missed miscarriage in between my two children, which was a difficult time for me. It was emotionally challenging, but thankfully, I was able to go on to have two successful vaginal deliveries. Since then, I've decided not to plan for any more pregnancies, and I currently use an intrauterine device for contraception. Is there anything specific you’d like to know about my experiences during my pregnancies?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: When did you first seek prenatal care? What was that experience like?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
I first sought prenatal care shortly after I confirmed my pregnancies. For both of my pregnancies, I made an appointment with my healthcare provider as soon as I learned I was expecting. I remember feeling a mix of excitement and nervousness during those visits. The healthcare staff was generally supportive, and they took the time to answer my questions. I had regular check-ups, which included ultrasounds and routine tests to monitor both my health and the baby's development.

However, I did find the experience to be a bit overwhelming at times, especially with all the information being presented. It was crucial for me to have a supportive healthcare provider who could help guide me through the process. I appreciated the emphasis on prenatal vitamins and maintaining a healthy lifestyle during that time. 

I also had a lot of anxiety during my second pregnancy due to my previous miscarriage, which made it difficult to fully relax and enjoy the experience. Thankfully, the care I received helped alleviate some of those fears. 

How about you? Do you want to hear more about the specific aspects of my prenatal care, like the types of tests I had or my interactions with the healthcare providers?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: Who is providing your prenatal care? Can you describe your relationship with your healthcare provider?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
I received my prenatal care from my primary care physician, who specializes in women's health. I had a good relationship with her; she was very approachable and always made time to address my concerns. I felt comfortable discussing any issues I had, whether they were related to my physical health or emotional well-being during my pregnancies.

During my visits, she was thorough and would explain the purpose of each test or procedure, which I appreciated. It made me feel more involved in my care and helped me understand what to expect throughout the pregnancies. I also appreciated that she encouraged me to ask questions, which helped ease my anxiety.

In addition to my primary care physician, I saw an OB-GYN for my deliveries. I felt well supported by both providers, and they worked together to ensure that I received comprehensive care. Overall, I would say my experiences with my healthcare providers during pregnancy were largely positive. 

Do you want to know more about any specific interactions or aspects of that care?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: How often do you have prenatal appointments? Can you walk me through what a typical visit is like?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
During my pregnancies, I typically had monthly prenatal appointments in the first and second trimesters, which then became bi-weekly as I approached my due date. Each visit usually lasted about 30 minutes to an hour, depending on what was needed that day.

A typical visit would start with the nurse taking my vital signs, including my blood pressure and weight. Since I have hypertension, this was particularly important to monitor. After that, I would meet with my doctor, who would ask how I was feeling and if I had any concerns or questions. 

We would review any lab results from previous tests, such as blood work or ultrasounds. During the visits, I often had an ultrasound to check on the baby's growth and heartbeat, which was always a highlight for me. It was amazing to see the baby on the screen! 

My doctor would also discuss topics like nutrition, exercise, and any symptoms I might be experiencing. I appreciated that she took the time to explain things thoroughly and would often provide pamphlets or resources to take home. By the end of the visit, I would feel reassured and more informed about what was happening with my pregnancy.

After the second trimester, we started discussing birth plans and any preparations I needed to make for labor and delivery. I felt well-prepared going into my deliveries thanks to those discussions.

Was there anything in particular about the appointment process or what I experienced during those visits that you’d like me to elaborate on?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: Have you experienced any health concerns or complications during your pregnancy?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
During my pregnancies, I was fortunate that I didn't experience any significant health complications. However, I did have to manage my hypertension, which was a concern throughout both pregnancies. My healthcare provider was proactive about monitoring my blood pressure and adjusting my medication as needed to ensure it was controlled. 

I also had some mild symptoms related to my chronic sinusitis, which would sometimes flare up due to changes in hormones and increased blood flow. It was uncomfortable at times, but nothing that significantly impacted my pregnancies. 

The missed miscarriage I experienced in between my two pregnancies was tough emotionally, and it weighed heavily on my mind during my subsequent pregnancies. I often worried about the health of my babies and whether everything would go smoothly. Thankfully, with the support of my healthcare providers, I was able to navigate those feelings and focus on the positive aspects of my pregnancies.

Overall, while I had some concerns, I felt supported and informed by my healthcare team, which helped me manage any issues that arose. Do you want to explore any specific health concerns or complications further?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: What medications or supplements are you currently taking?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
Currently, I take medication to manage my hypertension, which is essential for keeping my blood pressure within a healthy range. The specific medication I’m on is a common one, and I've been able to maintain good control with it, thanks to regular monitoring.

In addition to that, I take prenatal vitamins, even though I'm not currently pregnant. I feel that it's important to maintain my overall health, especially since I have two teenagers who I want to keep up with. I also take a daily vitamin D supplement, as my doctor recommended that due to some concerns about my levels being on the lower side.

I always make sure to discuss any new medications or supplements with my healthcare provider to ensure they are safe and appropriate for me, especially considering my hypertension. Is there anything else you'd like to know about my medication regimen or how I manage my health?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: Can you tell me about your diet and nutrition during pregnancy?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
During my pregnancies, I tried to focus on maintaining a balanced and nutritious diet, as I knew it was important for both my health and the health of my babies. I made an effort to include a variety of foods in my meals, such as fruits, vegetables, whole grains, lean proteins, and healthy fats. 

I paid special attention to getting enough folic acid, iron, and calcium, which I knew were crucial during pregnancy. I would often incorporate foods like leafy greens, beans, nuts, and dairy products into my diet. I also made a point to stay hydrated, drinking plenty of water throughout the day.

However, I did face some challenges with cravings and nausea, particularly during the first trimester. I found that I had an aversion to certain smells and foods, which made it tricky to stick to my ideal diet. I learned to listen to my body and sometimes opted for what I could tolerate, even if it wasn’t always the healthiest choice.

I also received guidance from my healthcare provider about nutrition, which was helpful. They provided resources and tips on meal planning and healthy snacks. I remember being encouraged to limit processed foods and sugar, which I tried to do, especially since I was also managing my hypertension.

Overall, I aimed to create a well-rounded diet, but there were moments when it was more about getting through the day and managing my symptoms. Do you want to know more about how my dietary choices evolved during the different trimesters or how I balanced my nutrition with my busy lifestyle?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: How have you been feeling emotionally during your pregnancy?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
During my pregnancies, my emotional experience was quite a rollercoaster. I started off feeling really excited and hopeful, especially when I first learned I was pregnant. However, that excitement was often mixed with anxiety, particularly due to my missed miscarriage in between my pregnancies. The fear of experiencing another loss lingered in the back of my mind, especially during the early stages.

In my first trimester, I found myself feeling a bit overwhelmed with all the changes happening in my body and the responsibilities of preparing for a new baby. The hormonal fluctuations also contributed to mood swings, which made it challenging at times. I remember having moments of joy and anticipation, but I also struggled with worry about the health of the baby and whether I was doing everything right.

As my pregnancies progressed, I started to feel more confident, especially after seeing the ultrasound images and hearing the heartbeat. Those moments were incredibly reassuring and helped alleviate some of my anxiety. I made an effort to focus on the positive aspects and surrounded myself with supportive friends and family who helped lift my spirits.

I also made it a point to communicate openly with my healthcare provider about my emotional well-being. I found that discussing my feelings helped me process them better, and I appreciated having someone to talk to who understood my concerns. 

By the time I reached the later trimesters, I was generally feeling more positive, although the physical discomforts of pregnancy sometimes made me irritable or tired. I tried to take care of myself through relaxation techniques, like deep breathing and gentle exercise, which helped improve my mood.

Overall, it was a mixture of highs and lows, but the support from my healthcare team and loved ones made a significant difference in how I managed those emotional challenges. Would you like to explore any specific aspects of my emotional experience further?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: Who supports you during your pregnancy? Can you tell me about your support network?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
During my pregnancies, I was fortunate to have a strong support network that really helped me navigate the ups and downs. My family played a crucial role; my parents were very supportive and always checked in on me. They were eager to help with my children and offered emotional support whenever I needed it. 

I also had a couple of close friends who had gone through pregnancies themselves, and their experiences and advice were invaluable. They really understood what I was going through, and it was comforting to share my thoughts and feelings with them. We would often meet up to chat or go for walks, which helped me stay active and connected.

In addition to my family and friends, I relied on my healthcare providers for professional support. My primary care physician was always available to discuss any concerns I had, both physical and emotional. I felt comfortable reaching out to her when I needed reassurance or guidance.

I also attended some prenatal classes that were offered through my healthcare provider's office. It was great to meet other expecting mothers and share experiences. Those classes not only provided useful information but also built a sense of community among us.

Overall, I felt that having a diverse support network made a significant difference in my pregnancy experiences. It allowed me to feel less alone and more prepared for the challenges ahead. Do you want to know more about any specific individuals in my support network or how they helped me during my pregnancies?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: Have you thought about your birth plan? What are your preferences for delivery?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
During my pregnancies, I did think quite a bit about my birth plan and what my preferences were for delivery. I wanted to have a clear idea of how I envisioned the labor and delivery process, especially since I had already experienced it twice before.

Both times, I opted for vaginal deliveries, and I was hopeful to have a similar experience again. I discussed my preferences with my healthcare providers during my prenatal appointments. I wanted to ensure that I would have a supportive environment, and that my partner, who was my ex-husband, would be present with me during labor.

I also expressed a desire to have as natural a birth as possible, but I was open to using pain relief options if needed. I appreciated that my healthcare team was understanding and supportive of my wishes. They provided me with information about different pain management techniques, including epidurals and natural pain relief methods, which helped me feel prepared for whatever situation arose.

In terms of my birth environment, I preferred a calm and peaceful atmosphere. I wanted to have music playing and to be able to move around during labor as much as possible. I also hoped to have skin-to-skin contact with my babies immediately after delivery, which was something I valued from my previous experiences.

Overall, I felt that having a birth plan helped me feel more in control and informed about what to expect. However, I was also aware that things might not go exactly as planned, and I was willing to be flexible if necessary. 

Is there anything specific you’d like to know about my birth plan preferences, or perhaps how I felt during the actual delivery process?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: What sources of information have you used to learn about pregnancy and childbirth?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
During my pregnancies, I utilized a variety of sources to learn about pregnancy and childbirth. One of my primary sources was my healthcare provider. I found that my doctor was very informative and provided me with pamphlets and resources during my appointments, which helped me understand what to expect at each stage of the pregnancy.

I also read several books on pregnancy and childbirth. There were a couple of popular titles that I found particularly helpful, like "What to Expect When You're Expecting." Those books offered practical advice and covered a wide range of topics, from nutrition to labor techniques, which helped me feel more prepared.

Online resources were another tool I relied on. I joined a few reputable forums and websites where I could connect with other expecting mothers. These platforms allowed me to share experiences and ask questions, which was comforting. I made sure to verify the information I found online with credible sources, as I wanted to ensure I was getting accurate advice.

In addition to books and online resources, I attended prenatal classes offered by my healthcare provider. These classes covered topics such as childbirth preparation, breastfeeding, and newborn care. I found them to be incredibly valuable, as they not only provided information but also allowed me to meet other expectant parents. It was nice to share experiences and learn together.

Lastly, I leaned on my friends and family who had gone through pregnancies themselves. Their firsthand experiences and tips were invaluable, and I appreciated their willingness to share both the challenges and joys of motherhood.

Overall, I tried to gather information from a variety of sources to get a well-rounded understanding of what to expect during pregnancy and childbirth. Is there a specific area of information or resource you'd like me to elaborate on?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: How are you managing the financial aspects of pregnancy and preparing for a baby?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
During my pregnancies, managing the financial aspects was definitely a consideration, especially since I was navigating life as a single parent after my divorce. I was fortunate to have good healthcare access through Medicare, which covered most of my prenatal care costs. That alleviated a significant financial burden, as I didn't have to worry too much about copays for regular appointments or necessary tests.

However, I still had to budget for other expenses related to pregnancy and preparing for a new baby. I made it a point to save in advance for things like maternity clothes, baby gear, and nursery supplies. I created a list of essentials and prioritized what I needed versus what I wanted. For example, I focused on getting the basics like a crib, car seat, and stroller, while holding off on more decorative items that could wait.

I also looked into local resources and programs that offered assistance for new mothers. There were community programs that provided free or low-cost baby items, which was a great help. I utilized online marketplaces and second-hand stores to find good deals on items like clothes and toys, which allowed me to stretch my budget further.

When it came time to plan for delivery, I set aside some additional funds for any potential out-of-pocket expenses, such as hospital fees or unexpected medical costs. I also communicated with my healthcare provider about any anticipated costs early on, so I could plan accordingly.

Overall, I felt that being proactive about my finances and utilizing available resources helped me manage the financial aspects of pregnancy better. I tried to balance being practical with wanting to create a welcoming environment for my new baby. 

Is there anything specific you'd like to know about the financial aspects of my pregnancies, or perhaps tips on budgeting for a new baby?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: How has your pregnancy affected your work or employment situation?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
During my pregnancies, there were definitely some impacts on my work and employment situation, but I was fortunate to have a supportive environment. As a high school teacher, I had to navigate balancing my responsibilities at work with the physical and emotional changes that come with pregnancy.

Initially, I was concerned about how my pregnancies would affect my teaching schedule and my ability to manage my classroom. However, I found that my school administration was understanding and accommodating. They allowed me to adjust my workload as needed, especially during the first trimester when I was dealing with nausea and fatigue. I was able to take some sick days and plan for my maternity leave in advance, which helped me feel more at ease.

As I got further along, I made sure to communicate openly with my colleagues and students about my situation. I wanted to ensure that my students were supported during my absence, so I worked on a plan to transition my classes to a substitute teacher and prepared materials in advance. I found that having a clear plan helped me feel more comfortable about taking the time I needed for my health and my growing family.

Returning to work after each pregnancy was a bit challenging, however. I had to readjust to the demands of my job while also managing the new responsibilities of motherhood. I found it helpful to connect with other working mothers who shared their experiences and tips on balancing work and family life. 

Overall, I felt supported by my school and colleagues throughout my pregnancies, which made the transition smoother. Is there anything specific you'd like to explore about how pregnancy affected my work life, or perhaps any challenges I faced during that time?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: Have you thought about the postpartum period? What plans do you have for after the baby arrives?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
During my pregnancies, I definitely thought about the postpartum period and what it would entail. I understood that the time after delivery would be just as important as the pregnancy itself, and I wanted to be prepared for the physical and emotional adjustments that come with it.

One of my main focuses was to plan for recovery and self-care after childbirth. I knew that I would need time to heal physically, especially after vaginal deliveries. I made sure to discuss postpartum recovery with my healthcare provider during my prenatal appointments, which helped me understand what to expect and how to manage any discomfort or complications that might arise.

Emotionally, I was aware of the potential for postpartum mood changes, especially considering my previous experience with anxiety during pregnancy. I made a plan to stay connected with my support network, including family and friends, who could help me during that transition. I felt that having people around me who understood what I was going through would be beneficial.

I also wanted to establish a routine that would allow me to balance caring for my new baby with my responsibilities at home and at work. I thought about how I would manage breastfeeding or formula feeding, and I planned to attend a breastfeeding class to help prepare myself for that aspect. I was open to different feeding options, depending on what worked best for me and my baby.

In terms of practical preparations, I made sure to stock up on essentials like diapers, wipes, and newborn clothes before the baby arrived. I also planned for some meals in advance, so I wouldn't have to worry as much about cooking during the early days postpartum.

Overall, I aimed to approach the postpartum period with flexibility and an open mind, knowing that things might not go exactly as planned. I wanted to give myself grace as I navigated the challenges of motherhood. 

Is there anything specific you’d like to know about my postpartum plans or how I prepared for that period?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: Thank you for your time and for sharing your experiences with me. This concludes our interview.
